text.content: This time tomorrow, I will be sitting on a beach. At 3 PM, I will be attending a meeting. Next week, they will be traveling around Europe. Tomorrow at this time, she will be flying to New York. This time next month, we will be living in our new house. At 9 o'clock tonight, I will be watching my favorite show. Next year, I will be studying at university. Tomorrow morning, they will be driving to the mountains.

text.content: Will you be using the car tonight? Will you be going to the supermarket? If so, could you buy some milk? Will you be passing the post office? Could you post this letter? Will you be seeing John later? Can you give him this message? Will you be working late tomorrow? Will you be coming to the party on Saturday? Will you be staying long? Will you be needing the computer this afternoon?

text.content: By next week, I will have been working here for five years. This time next year, we will have been living in this city for a decade. By the time you arrive, I will have been waiting for two hours. Next month, they will have been dating for six months. By December, she will have been studying English for three years. Tomorrow at noon, I will have been traveling for 24 hours. Next week, he will have been training for the marathon for six months.

overview.title: Future Continuous - In Progress
overview.subtitle: Actions in progress at a future time
overview.description: Use Future Continuous to describe actions that will be in progress at a specific future time.

uses.label: Action at specific future time
uses.example: At 3 PM, I will be meeting a client.

uses.label: In progress in the future
uses.example: This time tomorrow, I'll be flying to Paris.

commonErrors.correct: At 3 PM, I will be working.
commonErrors.explanation: Use continuous for action in progress at specific time.

examples.sentence: This time next week, I'll be relaxing on a beach.
Tomorrow at 8 AM, she'll be having breakfast.

overview.title: Future Continuous - Polite Questions
overview.subtitle: Ask about future plans politely
overview.description: Use Future Continuous in questions to ask about people's plans more politely than 'Will you...?'

affirmative.subject: Polite
affirmative.verb: Will you be using the car?

uses.label: Polite questions
uses.example: Will you be going to the shop?

examples.sentence: Will you be coming to the meeting tomorrow?
Will you be needing the car tonight?

overview.title: Future Perfect Continuous - Duration
overview.subtitle: How long by a future time
overview.description: Use Future Perfect Continuous (will have been + -ing) to show duration up to a future point.

affirmative.subject: With time
affirmative.verb: will have been working for 5 years

uses.label: Duration to future point
uses.example: By next year, I'll have been living here for 10 years.

uses.label: Emphasis on length
uses.example: She'll have been studying for 3 hours by then.

examples.sentence: By 2030, I will have been working here for 20 years.
Next month, we'll have been dating for a year.
